data.title: Women of Distinction
data.text:
Shelley Brown Floyd

Shelley Brown Floyd grew up in Jackson, Mississippi, balancing school with time at Brown Bottling, where she enjoyed learning the business and spending time with family and friends. After graduating from Jackson Preparatory School, Shelley attended Mississippi State University, earning a Bachelor of Science in Apparel, Textiles, and Merchandising, with a minor in business. She then pursued an MBA in Business Administration from Millsaps College.

Shelley joined the family business, Brown Bottling Group, taking on various roles, including working on trucks, in the warehouse, in human resources, sales, marketing, and management. As Executive Vice President, she has been pivotal in expanding the company’s portfolio, developing a statewide distribution footprint, leveraging social media, and steering the business through a recent rebranding. She also works with Refresh Sips & Eats and Exell Companies.

In her personal time, Shelley enjoys traveling and making memories with her family. She is active in the community, serving on the board of the Central Mississippi Down Syndrome Society, the SPRC committee at Madison Methodist Church, and supporting The Lily Pad, a nonprofit cafe for training adults with intellectual and developmental disabilities.

Shelley and her husband Patrick have been married for 12 years and have two children: eight-year-old Aiden, who is known for making friends easily, and six-year-old Blair, who is already showing leadership potential.

Candie L. Simmons

Candie is a seasoned marketing professional with over 20 years of experience in corporate America and non-profit organizations. Known for her engaging presentations and speeches, she is a highly sought-after public speaker who excels in content delivery and audience engagement. As a Gallup Certified StrengthsFinder® Coach, Candie has successfully coached numerous managers and their teams, helping them work together more effectively by leveraging their individual strengths to achieve overall goals.

A native of Ocean Springs, Mississippi, Candie holds a Bachelor of Business Administration in marketing and a Master of Business Administration from the University of Mississippi. She is the founder of CLSimmons Consulting, LLC, a full-service boutique consulting firm that enhances organizational effectiveness through marketing and professional development training. The firm offers services such as executive coaching, team building, strategic planning sessions, personal brand development, and communication training.

Candie has been recognized by the Mississippi Business Journal as a 'Top 40 Under 40' and a 'Top 50 Leading Business Woman,' where she placed in the top ten. In 2017, she was named 'Outstanding Young Alumni of the Year' by the University of Mississippi and 'A Woman Making a Difference in Madison County' by Delta Sigma Theta Sorority's Madison County Alumnae Chapter. The Diabetes Foundation of Mississippi has also honored her as a Woman of Excellence.

A former C-Suite executive, Candie is not only a business leader but also a dedicated community member. She serves on the Ole Miss Women's Council, the Ole Miss Banking and Finance Advisory Board, and the Junior League of Jackson Business and Community Advisory Council. She also chairs the Marketing and Community Investment Committee for the First Commercial Bank's Board of Directors and is involved with 2nd Chance Mississippi, the Baptist Health Foundation, and the Coleman Alexander Prosser Foundation, Incorporated, where she serves as Treasurer. Additionally, Candie is actively involved with Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated® Beta Delta Omega Chapter, where she is the immediate past president and the South Eastern representative to the International Programs Committee, demonstrating her commitment to community service.

Jennie M. Simmons

Jennie Simmons is a third-generation entrepreneur and highway contractor, serving as the President/CEO of Simmons Erosion Control, Inc. Based in Mississippi, her company has been a prominent player in highway construction throughout the southeastern United States for over 25 years. As the eldest of four siblings, Jennie hails from a family with a successful entrepreneur in each independent branch. She earned a Bachelor of Science degree in Business and Communication from Mississippi State University and has pursued additional coursework towards an MBA from MSU, along with continuing education from Harvard Business School online.

Jennie holds multiple state professional licenses in highway, street, and bridge construction, as well as electrical construction. Under her leadership, Simmons Erosion Control has become one of the largest specialty concrete construction firms in Mississippi, handling extensive projects including bridge railings, barrier walls, curbs, gutters, sidewalks, driveways, and inlet drains across the state. She also serves as the Investment Chair on the Board of Directors for the Associated Builders and Contractors Association of Mississippi. Appointed by Mississippi Treasurer David McRae, she is a member of the Mississippi Business Finance Corporation and the Mississippi Development Bank.

Committed to giving back, Jennie believes in making a positive impact and leaving the world better than she found it. She dedicates significant time to volunteering and contributes financially to her church, her children’s school, and various nonprofit organizations in the metro Jackson area. Jennie is a member of the Make-A-Wish Mississippi Board of Directors, the 2024 Jackson Symphony League Board of Directors Vice President for the Sub-Debs program, a 2024 Woman of Impact Honoree for Metro Jackson Go Red for Women, and the 2024 Tickled Pink Luncheon Chair for the American Cancer Society.

Jennie finds her greatest joy in her faith and family. She has been married to Chris for over 25 years and is the mother of Katie Beth, Kariana, and Krissi Joe. The family recently relocated from Lake to Gluckstadt and attends the First Baptist Church of Flora.

Elizabeth J. Randall

Elizabeth is the Founder and President of Randall Commercial Group, LLC, a boutique commercial real estate investment and advisory firm operating in 13 states. The firm serves individual, institutional, developer, and publicly traded company investors across the U.S. Elizabeth was named to the Mississippi Top CEO List by the Mississippi Business Journal, and Randall Commercial Group was recognized on the 2023 Inc. 5000 List of Fastest Growing Private Companies in the U.S.

Elizabeth serves on the Board of Directors for First Commercial Bank and is a frequent speaker on commercial real estate investment strategies, sale leasebacks, healthcare real estate, philanthropy, and female entrepreneurship and leadership. She began her career in New York City as a risk analyst for an M&A transactions team. She holds five NASD securities licenses and has worked as a public securities research analyst with Bloomberg Certifications and as a real estate economist.

Philanthropy is a central part of Elizabeth’s life. She co-founded and chairs St. Jude Children’s Hospital Taste of Oxford and is a member and past chair of the Ole Miss Women’s Council for Philanthropy. Elizabeth also serves as a trustee for the Algernon Sydney Sullivan Foundation, North Mississippi Medical Center Foundation, A.J. Brown Foundation, the UM Real Estate Advisory Board, and the Innovation and Entrepreneurship Advisory Board. She is on the Executive Committee and Board of Directors for the Ole Miss Foundation. Elizabeth volunteers as the Executive-in-Residence at Insight Park and co-founded and chairs the Khayat Lecture Series at Ole Miss. She is a member of CHIEF, a national organization for female executives, and has received numerous honors including National Volunteer of the Year for St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital, Outstanding Young MBA Alumnus Award, and was named one of the Top 10 Leading Women in Business by the Mississippi Business Journal. She has also been honored by Argent Trust for National Women in Business Day and received the Outstanding Alumna Cable Award from Delta Gamma Sorority.

Elizabeth is a fourth-generation Ole Miss graduate with a Bachelor's and a Master of Business Administration. She was named Mississippi’s Swayze Scholar by The Bankers’ Association and has completed executive education at New York University and the University of Chicago Booth School of Business. Elizabeth and her husband Trace have five young children.

Gloria B. Johnson

Gloria Johnson hails from the small community of Delta City in the Mississippi Delta. She earned a Bachelor of Science degree in Business Administration from Mississippi Valley State University and a master's degree in Business Administration from Delta State University. Gloria is an alumna of Leadership Mississippi, Leadership Jackson, and Leadership Madison County and was recognized in 2004 as one of the state’s “50 Leading Businesswomen.”

Gloria retired in May 2016 after a long career with Entergy, which she joined in 1987. She began her professional journey at Baxter Travenol Laboratories in Cleveland, MS, and then worked as a Cost Services Coordinator for nine years at Uncle Ben’s Foods in Greenville, MS, before moving to Entergy, where she advanced in Customer Service.

Gloria is a member of Anderson United Methodist Church and has been deeply involved in her community. She is a lifetime member of Girl Scouts of the USA and has chaired the Board of Directors for Girl Scouts of Greater Mississippi. Additionally, she has served as chairman of the Board of Directors for the Madison County Chamber of Commerce, Mississippi Council on Economic Education, American Association of Blacks in Energy (Mississippi Chapter), Public Education Forum of Mississippi, Keep Mississippi Beautiful, and Leadership Mississippi. She has also been a board member for the Mississippi Economic Council, Mississippi Housing Partnership, Mississippi Ecenter at Jackson State University, American Red Cross Advisory Board, Willowood Developmental Center, Jobs for Mississippi Graduates, and the Metro Jackson Chamber of Commerce. Her community service has earned her numerous recognitions, including the “Goodwill Salute Volunteer” award in 2017.

Gloria is a member of the Beta Delta Omega Chapter of Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Inc., and The Links, Inc., Jackson, Mississippi Chapter. She lives by the philosophy: “Consider life as a journey; live each day to its fullest, helping others along the way.”

Gloria is married to Kenneth Johnson. They have one son, Brian, a daughter-in-law, Christina, and two adorable grandchildren, Nova Marie and Bronx.

Jamie Boteler Higdon

Jamie, a second-generation professional in the staffing and recruiting industry, brings extensive knowledge and experience as the President of TempStaff. Headquartered in Jackson with branch offices in Batesville, Grenada, Greenwood, Canton, and Brookhaven, TempStaff is Mississippi's premier staffing agency.

Jamie’s journey in the industry began early, observing her mother manage TempStaff, which gave her a deep understanding and natural talent for connecting people with opportunities. As a college student, she worked as an intern in TempStaff’s accounting department, further honing her skills. Jamie holds both a bachelor’s and a master’s degree in Business Administration from Mississippi College, providing her with a strong foundation in business principles and strategic planning that she applies in her role as President.

Jamie and her husband Scott have been married for twenty-five years and have two daughters: Sydney, a senior, and Karlie, a freshman at Florence High School. They are active members of First Baptist Church Florence. Jamie is deeply involved in her community, both professionally and personally. She serves as the Board of Directors Region 2 Vice President for TempNet, the premier association of dynamic, independently owned staffing firms in the US, and has previously served as President of the Rankin County Chamber. She is a graduate of Leadership Mississippi 2013 and Leadership Rankin 2004. Recognized by the Mississippi Business Journal, Jamie was a Top 10 Finalist for both the 2015 50 Leading Business Women in Mississippi and 2015 Top 50 Under 40. She was named a 2023 American Heart Association Woman of Impact and the 2021 Make-A-Wish Mississippi Society Woman of the Year. Jamie is also actively involved in various parent organizations at her daughters’ schools, having served in numerous leadership roles and being honored as Parent of the Year at Steen’s Creek Elementary, Florence Elementary, and Florence Middle Schools. She was named the 2024 Secondary Parent of the Year for Rankin County School District.

Amanda S. Fontaine

Amanda began her role as the Executive Director of the Mississippi Association of Broadcasters in July 2019. She also serves as the Executive Director of Hope Rising Mississippi and previously dedicated fifteen years as the Executive Director of the Mississippi Burn Foundation. Amanda is the Vice President of the Rotary Club of Jackson and chairs the American Heart Association’s Circle of Red and the Children’s Advocacy Center’s Protector’s Circle. Additionally, she is part of the steering committee for the Jackson Symphony League and the American Cancer Society’s Hope Ball. Amanda holds positions on the UMMC Advisory Board, the Southwest American Red Cross Board, and the Boy Scouts of America Executive Board. She is active with the Junior League of Jackson, serving on the Sustainers Steering Committee, and has previously co-chaired Mistletoe and chaired Touch A Truck Jackson.

Her past leadership roles include serving as Governor of Rotary District 6820, District Governor of the American Advertising Federation AAF District 7, a member of the National Board of Directors of the American Advertising Federation, President of the American Association of Fundraising Professionals, and President of the Rankin County Chamber of Commerce. She has also been President of the Rankin County Rotary Club, the YMCA Rankin County Advisory Board, and the American Advertising Federation of Jackson. Additionally, Amanda was Vice President of the National Association of Junior Auxiliaries and a member of the Crossgates River Oaks Hospital Advisory Board, the Delta State University Alumni Association Board of Directors, and the Metro YMCA Board of Directors.

Amanda has been recognized as one of Mississippi Business Journal’s Top 50 Women in Business and Mississippi Delta’s Top 50 Women in Business. She was appointed by the Governor to serve on the EMS Advisory Council. Her accolades include the Rankin County Junior Auxiliary Community Volunteer of the Year Award, Empowering Progressive Women’s Association Honoree, Cambridge Who’s Who Among Executive and Professional Women, International Who’s Who of Professional Management, the 7th District of the American Advertising Federation Governor’s Award, and President of the Year. She is also a recipient of the Daily Points of Light award and the Mississippi Healthcare Association Volunteer of the Year award.

Amanda and her family are active members of Pinelake Church. She is married to Patrick, and they have three children: Taylor, Wesley, and Sydney.

Katherine McCall McRae

Katie grew up as a first-generation Cuban American in a family dedicated to achieving the American Dream and giving back to their adopted country. Education played a significant role in that journey. After high school, Katie attended Southern Methodist University, where she met her husband David and earned a degree in English Literature. She later earned a Master’s degree in Strategic Public Relations with a focus on Crisis Management and Political Campaigns from the University of Southern California.

In 2005, Hurricane Katrina devastated the Gulf Coast, causing widespread destruction in southern and central Mississippi. In 2008, then-Governor Haley Barbour hired Katie and a team of dedicated public servants to oversee $5.4 billion in recovery efforts. Over the next six years, Katie worked in the Disaster Recovery Division of the Mississippi Development Authority, managing approximately $200 million in elevation grant funds and participating in the project management of multiple HUD CDBG grants.

After retiring from state government service, Katie became a full-time mom and philanthropist. Her charitable work includes chairing multiple events for the Children’s Hospital, raising over $1 million for the hospital, and chairing the Rembrandt Dinner and Art Gala for the Mississippi Museum of Art. She also played a key role in revitalizing Magnolia Speech School’s “Hope Cup,” one of Mississippi’s premier charity shooting events, which annually raises six-figure sums for the school. Katie is actively involved with the Miss Mississippi Scholarship Organization, Junior League of Jackson, Habitat for Humanity, and the University of Mississippi Medical Center advisory board.

Katie grew up in a bilingual household in Vero Beach, Florida. Her mother’s family fled Cuba in the early 1960s during the Cuban revolution, bringing with them a strong sense of family, patriotism, education, and resilience. Her father, a former University of Florida football player and 45-year veteran of the insurance industry, instilled in her a love for the outdoors, community, and country. Katie now lives in Ridgeland with her husband David, the State Treasurer of Mississippi, and their three children and four dogs.

H. Ann. C. Jones

Born in Magnolia, MS, in 1944, H. Ann was educated in the segregated Pike County public schools, graduating as valedictorian from the Eva Gordon Attendance Center. She earned a Bachelor of Science in Biology from Dillard University and a Master of Science in Immunology from Tuskegee University.

In 1977, H. Ann moved to Jackson, MS, and founded one of Mississippi’s most successful businesses, Minority’s In Action. As MINACT flourished, H. Ann embraced a second career as a community volunteer and advocate for children. Her Girl Scout service began in 1977 when she started Troop 423, the first integrated troop in Mississippi. She continued her service by being elected to the board of the Middle Mississippi Girl Scout Council and later served nine years on the Girl Scouts USA National Board, including time as the Nominating Chair.

H. Ann has consistently worked to improve the education and lives of children through her involvement with the Parent Teacher Association, Girl Scouts of America, Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, and Jack and Jill Inc. She was appointed to various committees and boards, including the Mayor’s Committee to study the form of Government for the City of Jackson, Governor Winter’s Task Force on Educational Reform, and Mayor Johnson’s Convention Center Campaign Committee. Additionally, she served on the Board of Directors for Leadership Jackson, Youth Leadership Jackson, Jackson Chamber of Commerce, Hinds County Foster Care Review Board, Methodist Hospital Board, United Way Advisory Board, Hinds County Board for the Prevention of Blindness, Piney Woods Country Life School, and many others. She also served thirteen years on the Jackson Public Schools Board of Trustees.

H. Ann concluded her public service as a member of the Commission on School Accreditation of the Mississippi State Board of Education. She is a member of the Beta Delta Omega Chapter of Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Inc., and an alumna member of the Jackson Chapter of The Links Incorporated. She holds lifetime memberships in Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, the NAACP, Girl Scouts of America, Jack & Jill of America, and the Mississippi Congress of PTA. H. Ann has two daughters, three grandchildren, and two grand-dogs.

Davetta Cooke Lee

Davetta Lee is honored to be named a Woman of Distinction. A lifelong service-oriented individual, she has consistently worked towards making a sustainable impact in the world. As a former Girl Scout and dedicated community servant, she is committed to improving the lives of others through her professional and community engagements.

Davetta serves as Counsel and Policy Advisor for the Public Employees’ Retirement System of Mississippi, a $30 billion retirement system comprising four defined benefit plans and two defined contribution plans. She is responsible for the system’s legislation, regulations, and policies, as well as the internal administration of the defined contribution plans. Prior to joining PERS, she served as the Executive Director of the Mississippi Access to Justice Commission, where she worked to improve access to civil legal proceedings for the poor in Mississippi. Davetta is a graduate of Xavier University of Louisiana and Mississippi College School of Law.

Davetta holds active memberships and has held leadership roles in professional organizations including the Mississippi Bar, Capital Area Bar Association, National Association of Public Pension Attorneys, National Association of State Retirement Administrators, and the National Association of Government Defined Contribution Administrators.

In addition to her professional responsibilities, Davetta is very active in her community. She is the immediate past president of the LeFleur’s Bluff (MS) Chapter of The Links, Incorporated, where she has held various leadership roles. She is also an active member of the Jackson (MS) Chapter of Jack and Jill of America, Incorporated, and the Jackson (MS) Alumnae Chapter of Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Incorporated. Davetta is a sustainer in the Junior League of Jackson and an active member of the Woodland Hills Garden Club.

Her accolades include being named one of Mississippi Business Journal’s Top 50 Under 40 and Mississippi College School of Law Young Alumni of the Year. Davetta is married to Jonathan Lee, and they have one daughter, Morgan Elizabeth. They reside in Jackson and are members of Anderson United Methodist Church.
